Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Field Investigation of Shallow Ground Improvement Methods for Inhibiting Liquefaction Triggering; Christchurch, New Zealand

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
In 2010-2011, the city of Christchurch, New Zealand was devastated by a series of powerful earthquakes, including six significant events. The February 2011 Christchurch Earthquake (movement magnitude, Mw, 6.2) generated the largest ground motions in the city, with horizontal peak ground accelerations between 0.37 and 0.52 g. The 2010-2011 earthquakes caused repeated liquefaction throughout the suburbs of Christchurch. Some key observations and impacts are that: (1) liquefaction was particularly extensive and damaging along the meandering loops of the Avon River, now designated as part of the ?Red Zone? (zone where structures will not be rebuilt), (2) more than 6,000 residential properties are being abandoned in the ?Red Zone? because the damage is beyond economic repair, (3) an estimated additional 15,000 properties were affected by liquefaction, and (4) the total economic loss is estimated to be from 25 to 30 billion NZ dollars (or 15 to 18% of New Zealand?s GDP). One critical problem facing Christchurch and the Canterbury region is rebuilding on land that remains at risk of liquefaction in future earthquakes. This problem arises after nearly all earthquakes and little information exists on ground improvement methods that can be used to increase the resilience of residential structures and low-rise buildings in future earthquakes. Facing this critical, time-sensitive problem, the New Zealand authorities are contributing about $1M (NZ) to a project involving full-scale field test trials of shallow ground improvement methods. The goal is to determine if and which ground improvement methods achieve the objectives of inhibiting liquefaction triggering in the improved ground and are cost-effective measures. This new knowledge, which is applicable in the U.S. and worldwide, is rapidly needed as part formulating the path forward in rebuilding the infrastructure in Christchurch and the Canterbury region. The New Zealand funds support all technical and logistical aspects of the project except the liquefaction testing. The liquefaction testing will be conducted using the large mobile shaker, called T-Rex, that is operated by NEES@UTexas. T-Rex will be used to simulate a wide range of controlled earthquake shaking levels. This unique opportunity exists because T-Rex is already in Christchurch as a result of an earlier NEESR project involving deep seismic profiling. This work includes the collection and interpretation of a one-of-a-kind dataset that can be used in the design of shallow ground improvement methods to inhibit liquefaction triggering of saturated soils. This knowledge does not exist but has numerous applications in earthquake-prone areas in the U.S. and worldwide for residential structures and low-rise commercial buildings. Additionally, pore water pressure generation in nearly-saturated, liquefaction-prone soils will, for the first time, be collected in the field. This new knowledge will help develop a more comprehensive understanding of this risk and ways to mitigate it.

The broader impacts of this research are extensive. The study will impact the future Christchurch society at large through development of more robust seismic designs of residential structures for more than 15,000 homes. Furthermore, new knowledge will be developed for designing ground improvements to inhibit liquefaction triggering that will transfer directly to U.S. cities such as Seattle, WA, Los Angeles, CA, Memphis, TN, and Charleston, SC. The new knowledge will also transfer to earthquake-prone countries worldwide such as China, Chile, Haiti, Japan, Taiwan and Turkey. The work will strengthen international research collaborations and will provide U.S. graduate students with rewarding international travel experiences that will balance their technical education and e expose them to the globally-connected problems that still exist in earthquake engineering

In 2010-2011, the city of Christchurch, New Zealand was devastated by a series of powerful earthquakes, including four significant events.  The February 2011 Christchurch Earthquake (movement magnitude, Mw, 6.2) generated the largest ground motions in the city, with horizontal peak ground accelerations between 0.37 and 0.52 g.  The 2010-2011 earthquakes caused repeated liquefaction throughout the suburbs of Christchurch.  Some key observations and impacts were that: (1) liquefaction was particularly extensive and damaging along the meandering loops of the Avon River, now designated as part of the “Red Zone” (zone where structures will not be rebuilt), (2) more than 10,000 residential properties had to be abandoned in the “Red Zone” because the damage was beyond economic repair, (3) an estimated additional 20,000 properties were severely affected by liquefaction, and (4) the total economic loss was estimated to be about 40 billion NZ dollars (or 20% of New Zealand’s GDP).  One critical problem that is facing Christchurch and the Canterbury region is rebuilding on land that remains at risk of liquefaction in future earthquakes.  This problem arises after most large earthquakes. Unfortunately, little information exists on ground improvement methods that can be used to increase the resilience of residential structures and low-rise buildings in future earthquakes.

With this critical, time-sensitive problem, the New Zealand authorities have contributed about $6M (NZ) to a project involving full-scale field test trials of shallow ground improvement methods that possibly inhibit the adverse effects of liquefaction triggering in future earthquakes. The goal is to determine if and which ground improvement methods achieve the objective of inhibiting liquefaction triggering and are cost-effective measures. This new knowledge, which is applicable in the U.S. and worldwide, is rapidly needed as part of formulating the path forward in rebuilding a resilient infrastructure in Christchurch and the Canterbury region. The New Zealand funds have supported all technical and logistical aspects of the project except for the liquefaction testing. The liquefaction testing was conducted using the large mobile shaker, called T-Rex, that is operated by NEES@UTexas. T-Rex was used to simulate a wide range of controlled earthquake shaking levels on unimproved ground and on various types of improved ground. 

 In this NSF-funded research, field trials of four shallow ground improvement methods were originally proposed at two field locations in the Red Zone along the Avon River. This work was envisioned to require a campaign of several weeks of field testing in June or July, 2013. During the actual effort, the scope of the project essentially tripled, involving three separate campaigns, each ranging from 2.5 to 3.5 weeks, with a total testing time in Christchurch of slightly more than 2 months. Significant cost overruns occurred which the New Zealand Earthquake Commission covered. Instead of testing 5 test panels at two sites for a total of 10 T-Rex experiments as originally planned, a total of 29 T-Rex experiments were performed at three different sites in the Red Zone along the Avon River. We have created a unique and extensive data set. The critical, time-sensitive portion of these tests involved determining which ground improvements worked well in the sandy soils around the Christchurch area. The ground shaking with T-Rex determined that both dynamic compaction applied at the ground surface and installation of dense gravel columns could be used. However, site conditions in terms of soil type and layer depth and site constraints in terms of surrounding structures must be considered.
